Reviews.Title: A long time Q-see user discovers their newest product
Reviews.Author: HMMWV "God, Country, Corps"
Reviews.Content: I bought my first q-see DVR (digital video recorder) about 3 years ago right here on amazon.com.  It was known as a "PENTAPLEX" which meant you could do 5 things at the same time - record live video from multiple channels, backup the hard disk, view video remotely over the internet, view video locally on a TV set, and search through recordings to find out who took your recycle bin full of cans.  Pentaplex and Triplex are names given as to how many activities the unit can do simultaneously.That unit is still running after driving the neighborhood drug dealers out of their rent free abandoned home (and having them arrested numerous times - it povided key evidence of license plate numbers, video of drug deals going down, spousal abuse -- you name it the police department got it.  For that matter the PD could log in over the internet to check up on who was there if they wanted to)I live on a 2 block long road full of modern quiet 4500 sq ft homes, and across from me was a 60 year old 931 sq ft original house that had become the neighborhood drug hangout - a place to go smoke a bowl, ride your motorcycle through the front door of the house and out the back, to hook up with the homies, etc.  It definitely did not fit in - the crime rate rose - the house adjacent to the drug house was robbed 5 times in 3 months.  Both me and my next door neighbor installed MONITORED alarms and we formed our own neighborhood watch.  His was a .357 and mine was a 9mm.The Q-see was instrumental in getting rid of the trash.  It provided numerous photographic enlargements of license plates, video evidence used in court to convict the individual squatting there, and more 30 second drive by drug deals than I could count, happening every 3-5 minutes right in front of my house.I installed 8 cameras covering every angle possible, 2 PTZ (pan-tilt-zoom - like the casino's use) domes that I could controll remotely over the internet to see what is going on if I was not home, and motion detectors, microphones - all of this was OVERT meaning it was blatant that you were on camera if you came nearby - I had to put up a sign because legally I could not record voice without notifying the people (video is OK) due to wiretapping laws that are outdated, so I put my sign on the 60 year old tree in front of my house warning people they were under video and audio surveilance.  In 3 months we had the dealers out, the rightful owners back, they had to demolish the house because it was so badly damaged, and then they built a brand new 4500 sq ft home in keeping with the neighborhood.About Q-seeQ-see brings the  $12,000 DVR that the casinos use to catch card cheats down to the price a homeowner can afford.  I recommend any home first install a MONITORED alarm system and make it BLATANT that one is in place (big bell box outside in a conspicuous place) - this will rid yourself of 90% of the crime because criminals know where to look for these and when they find them, they walk on to your neighbor's house to rob instead.  After an alarm comes video evidence of WHO did WHAT and WHEN with PROOF.  Q-see gives you this.What do all the numbers mean?  What is H.264?When dealing with video (which is inherently analog) and you go to digitize it, you would normally find yourself swamped in data, because video is 30 pictures per second, each 740x480, full color (or b&W; at night with IR vision cameras).  Imagine a 1.3 megapixel camera taking 30 pictures per second - your memory card would be full in a couple minutes at the most.The broadcast industry faced the same problem when the FCC mandated that they "go digital" recently - there was not enough room on a channel to put raw high definition television.  So they did what we do on our PCs when we have a bunch of files - they compressed them.  This process is known as coding and decoding and is abbreviated CODEC for those of us who dont like to type alot.  MANY codecs exist - divx, h.264, h.263, mjpeg, etc.  H.264 however crams the best quality picture into the smallest amount of disk space.  It's used by the satellite providers to give you more channels than they could without it.  Best of all, it's free.  No royalties to pay.You're going to hear alot about frames per second.  1 video channel is 30 frames per second.  That's for one camera.  If you have 8 cameras, then it 8 times 30 or 240 frames per second that your 8 camera DVR must record (if you want smooth free flowing video like you are accustomed to on TV) - now you don't need free flowing video - you can cut from 30 to 15 frames per second and still get reasonably smooth video.  The point is that any DVR has a limit as to how many FPS (Frames per Second) it can record.  You get to decide which cameras get the best picture, and which ones only take 2 pictures per second (as an example) if you do not have 240 frames per second.The second number to throw at you is resolution.  VGA is 640x480 and is about VHS quality.  HD is 1920x1080 and will blow your mind after being accustomed to VGA quality video (blu ray is done in HD as an example)  In the world of surveilance video - the more pixels you choose to record, the less time you can record on a disk.  So they invented QVGA - which stands for quarter vga - they divide a VGA screen into 1/4ths and you are left with 320x240.  That's cell phone size video - and when you see it blown up onto a big screen tv set it looks pretty bad.  Another standard is CIF which is 352x288 pixels - better than qvga, but not as good as VGA (about VHS or the old video standard).What I like about this product is you can configure how much quality you assign from the product's ability to record to each camera.  That way the cameras for areas where people are standing (front door for example) take 3 frames per second of CIF or VGA quality video.  The cameras that cover high speeed motion - the street with cars zooming by or the sidewalk with bicycles, they can record at 30 frames per second for smooth video.  Again - for 8 channels you need 240 frames per second to record all 8 channels at full framerate (30 FPS).The good news!The 408 from q-see supports 240 frames per second, so every camera can have full motion video.  Cameras 1 and 2 are special though, as they are sampled at a higher resolution called D1 or 702x408 pixels (sure beats CIF) while cameras 3-8 are recorded at CIF resolution.  I've been getting by on JUST CIF for 3 years, so this is a step up!Can I Install it?  Is it legal?I am not an attorney, so this is not legal advice, but from what I found on the net, you can record video of your property without giving notice.  However, this product can also record audio.  To do that you must put up a sign in a conspicuous place that tells passers by that video and audio surveilance is in use - then you are compliant with all the laws.Can you install it - probably if you can wire an 8 track player into your 1977 buick.  Here's what you need to know.1  - everything you will need is on amazon.2  - I've reviewed most of it so read my reviews3  - my email is in my profile so if you get stuck email me4  - every camera needs 2 things - a video connection and 12 volts to run the camera.  x 8 cameras and you will want a 12 volt power panel like the one I reveiwed here: Q-See QS1018 12 Volt 12 AMP Power Distribution Panel Connects 18 Cameras5  - should you decide to record audio, you will need 1 - a microphone for each channel (8 of them) 2 - a mic to line level amplifier (about $20) 3 - some microphone cable.  This gets into recording gear - the sennheiser C2 is a good deal since you get 2 mics in a set, 4 sets would get you 8 mics, and they are very sensitive - able to hear a whisper at 100 feet.  But they need preamps.  ART Tube MP Microphone Preamp Here's just one example - it will only handle one microphone, and costs more than the mic, so you might look around for 8 channel preamps beause the microphone needs 48V to run itself, and it gives you a very low level output on a XLR connector (3pin pro stuff) - and you need to amplify that .007 volt signal to about .700 volts (100x or 20dB for those who speak dB) to run the line level inputs of the 408.  Of course you could opt to just have 2 microphones.6 - what's this I hear about night vision - it it that expensive military stuff?  No.  How night vision works is when the sun goes down a sensor tells the camera to turn on a whole bunch of IR LEDs (infrared light emitting diodes) - these look to have a dull red glow to you, but 36 of them shining into your front yard is like a 1000W light turned on.  Best part is the subject walking through can't tell - the infrared spectrum is beyond what us humans can see - so it still looks dark, except on your camera, where although its black and white, it is fully detailed with facial recognition possible.7 - How about motion detection - can these replace those alarm motion sensors.  The answer is: it depends.  Inside, I'd say yes, but outside, I'd say no. The reason is that IR is not visable to HUMANS, but BUGS love the stuff, especially spiders who spin webs over your camera lenses where it's nice and bright at night.  And that spider will trigger any motion detector - even if you kill off all the spiders, the number of flying insects that love IR light is amazing.  Every night I capture about 50-80 bugs flying through a motion capture zone.8 - what is a motion capture zone?  Your camera brings back a big area - as much as the lens lets it see - but you may not want to capture the entire area, just a sub part of it, such as your front walkway without getting the sidewalk.  You can exclude the sidewalk and the street but if someone or their dog comes into your front yard, you trigger the motion capture event, and it records until the motion stops.  This saves tons of storage by not having to store video of your front yard all night long.  It also gives you an idea of how long something happened - a 50Kbyte file is probably a bug - while a 1 megabyte file is probably a person.  In between are cars, people walking by, dogs, cats, etc.9 - how can I get rid of all those extra recordings and only get people.  Simple - you use a tool called a PIR (passive Infra Red) detector - it looks for the body's heat - they are about $40 at security stores, and guess what - they run off 12V and give back a signal when someone is walking through their protection zone (where you point them).  That signal that someone is DEFINITELY there can also be used to start the recording (there is a terminal block on the right lower rear panel where you hook up one sensor for each camera input - if someone crosses the sensor, they also start the recorder - but bugs, spiders, and all the tiny things won't set off the sensors.  Now you really cut down your night's recordings.  Indoors its not a problem unless you have a bug infestation in your house.  Get a bug zapper.10 - OK - I have all this stuff - how long will it record.  On my 16 channel system I can record for 17 days on a 1 TB disk drive.  One of the things I like about q-see is they let you use your own disk drive - say you just upgraded the 1TB disk that came in last years computer to a 2 TB disk and now its laying around, right?  q-see lets you open the case and change out their 500 gb sata drive for your 1000 gb sata drive and you just gave yourself twice as much storage.11 - do I need to use all 8 cameras.  Absolutely not.  You can use channels 1 and 2 which are the high quality channels only and add cameras later as problems develop - or you can do what I did - you have a dual system - overt cameras that people can see and avoid, and covert cameras that catch them when they do.  It's a great way to divide and conquer.Summed up, you will be running alot of coax cable (at least 8 pieces for a full system) - the cameras come with skinny coax, but I prefer rg-59 as a minimum and rg-6 for long runs.  Q-see also makes "siamese" cable - its coax with 2 power wires along with it - the advantage is from one reel you can run power and video without needing 2 separate spools of cable.Earlier I mentioned PTZ domes - these are loads of fun if you get a camera with a 400x zoom lens.  From my house I can zoom in on the stop sign at the end of the road and see the bolts that hold the sign on the pole!  You get an IR remote with the system much like your TV set, and there is an output for your TV set (composite video - 740x480 or so resolution).  There is also a higher resolution output for multiple images like at the quickiemart - it uses VGA monitors you have laying around when you went to hdmi or dvi for your video card.  That's one of the things I like about q-see - I can recycle alot of my computer equipment into surveilance gear.  I even went so far as to get a 1 in 4 out VGA distribution amplifier so I could see the q-see signal at many screens in my house.  My older unit has relay outputs which I wired to buzzers to tell me when someone was walking up to my door - I usually beat them to the door with the advance notice.  you can customize your system based on your skill as an electrician and programmer in software.  For indoor cameras, it intergrates nicely with your alarm system - program  your alarm to close a relay when a door or window is violated (opened) and have a camera (inexpensive 30 dollar type) pointed at that door inside - wire the relay from your house alarm to the alarm trigger for the camera associated with the corresponding door and you've just eliminated the need for the motion sensor (they are better outside at night)In summary, q-see has brought the ability to record security video to the consumer price range.  I do not recommend the shopping big-store specials that come with 8 cameras because the 8 cameras they come with are usually the cheap indoor variety, and often you want an outdoor camera instead.Q-see has been around for a long time and instroduced new features, like the ability to send video to your cellphone (in this model) Again - do you want a call about every moth at night?  If not - you need to use quality motion sensors to trigger the system.  With the internet connection you can view your 2nd house or cabin remotely over the net to check in on things. (again - start with a good alarm system and at least get a permit from the city - ours are shiny reflective like streetsigns and just a little flashlight warns the would be burglar that the PD will be there in 2 minutes if they break into this home)Good luck with your install.  It is a diy project, but plan a couple of weekends to fine tune the system.  When done, you can have a great surveilance coverage of your property.

Reviews.Title: Garbage
Reviews.Author: Kyle
Reviews.Content: I think all the good reviews for this product must be written by q-see's marketing team. This product is just worthless garbage. I've had it for less than a year and already two of the four cameras are filled on the inside with condensation rendering them worthless. After I was finally able to track down q-see's customer service number, it was just a leave a message and someone will call you back. They don't even have anyone answering the phone with customer service. I was dumbfounded. And of course no one called me back. Please, do yourself a favor and don't waste your hard earned money on this garbage.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product, top value.
Reviews.Author: EatKabab "EatKabab"
Reviews.Content: I just installed this in my home with my 5 existing cameras and I must say that I am extremely impressed with this sub $200 system.  It even has some features I wouldn't expect it to have.  Specifically, FOUR audio in ports.  Thats just unheard of even in much more expensive systems.  Usually they only have one or two audio ins.Support for ALL smart phone operating systems is EXCELLENT.  QSee has written a dedicated app "Meye" for each phone (Android, iPhone, Blackberry, Windows Mobile, Symbian, sorry no WP7)  It's VERY fast at streaming to my Android.  It all went together so easily I just couldn't believe it.  I bought this expecting to have to hack it here and there to get it to do what I want.As the very diligent reviewer above said, this is not a $3k security system, but it is more than plenty for any small to medium sized area.  You're not getting HD quality bank security footage with this thing, but man does it beat getting up to go see who's at the front door...or anywhere else around the house for that matter.  All I do is flip to channel 3 on any of my TV's or hit the Meye app on my phone (its almost instant!).A note:Setup was easy for me because I'm moderately tech savvy.  For network viewing, I had to fiddle with my network configuration due to the limitation on the DVR's IP address configs.  If you want to use a static IP it needs to have all 12 digits for some reason.  I couldn't get it to work with something like 192.168.1.5 (it needs like 192.168.100.005).  Consider using a static IP for devices that broadcast such as this one to assure you don't loose signal because your router decided to reset...

Reviews.Title: Excellent deal on an 8 channel system
Reviews.Author: gadget guy
Reviews.Content: **VIDEO REVIEW EXTENDED** Search y-tube for my channel, dfizzbom, and watch an almost eight minute extended review. Multiple vids covering the package, a camera mount hack, and how to setup the multi client software. Hope this will help all those interested in this system!Did a ton a shopping- this is a great deal. What you're really buying into with this package is an 8 channel dvr with pre installed hard drive, and the cables. This is the heart of the system. The cables are of typical quality and are fine. The dvr, from all that I have tweaked upon setup, is outstanding. This dvr rivals that of a much more expensive dvr we use at my employment where I monitor another camera system- MUCH more expensive. The dvr in this package is very capable. Big points for that. Note- I used a 15" LCD computer monitor via VGA and setup menus and cameras are perfectly sized. A 19" monitor is great, but not absolutely needed. Another note about resolution choices per channel. This dvr, greatly so, also includes HD-1 [half D1] as a choice on ALL channels too! So actually, from lowest resolution to highest, you have the choice of CIF on all channels, HD-1 on all channels, and D1 on the first two channels if you want that. HD-1 is a very nice step up from CIF and since all channels support it, it's really great. That's a nice feature in this dvr.The cameras is where you get into 'starter' kit. They are capable. They do very well in daylight. They can be tweaked in the dvr to have perfectly acceptable color representation and if you're not happy, you can also make them black and white. All doable. Face recognition is very very good in daylight, and I have my cams temporarily placed two stories up. The live feed has perfect real time movement- not studder steps in live mode. Where the cameras fall a bit short is angle of view and live picture quality at night. 53 degree angle can be fine if you're pointing straight out into the back yard from second story. But point it down to a space you want to cover, and the angle gets tight. Don't expect to cover the entire side of the house below from the peak of the roof when pointing down to the ground. Better to mount one camera under a first floor eve and side swipe the whole area for full coverage. The night vision does it's job too. I have mine pointing down to a doorway below from a second story window temporarily. The patio has an eco bulb for added light. The picture is grainy and would not make for easy identification. But, when I install the camera properly- under the first floor eve swiping that door area, it will crisp the image up and be fine. Proper placement and added light is a big plus at night. But remember, these are really starter cams and although they seem capable, obviously the cameras is the area that you'll look to upgrade over time. And that's fine- you get going right away with 8 acceptable cameras, beautiful thing. Since I'm using only five, I have three extra to put in line should one or more break, while I wait for replacements. That is the biggest reason I got double the channels and cameras I needed, not to mention the extra cables too.Remote veiwing works. I have no plans for mobile phone viewing presently, but remote pc veiwing is what I wanted and it works. It takes some studying to get a grip on how to do it. It's not hard if you read up. I SUPER HIGHLY recommend viewing this wonderful free video crash course-wifi-wiz.netIt's an integral part of setting up remote viewing for any consumer. Read and watch everything there, especially the ip cam section, and you'll be all set. I can offer a couple of tips quickly. Do not forward port 80. You won't be lucky- internet providers block that port and mine does as well. Avoiding that will save time and hassle. I forwarded port 89. Also, q-see manuals and vids suggest only TCP connection type setting in the router. In my experience, you need choose 'both'- TCP/UDP. One last tip- after initailly setting networking in the dvr to DHCP and after reboot, set it to STATIC and reboot. Then enter the new static IP of the dvr into your router and all should be fine. If you have a traditional simple cable modem [non-combo modem/router] and a router, the process will be much easier for you. Remote viewing is excellent. All three pc's have downloaded and show the remote view no problem. That's what I wanted mostly- to keep an eye on my home while I'm at work.You can try, but you won't find an 8 channel system with hard drive installed and EIGHT cameras included for this price anywhere at the moment. Don't miss the deal.

Reviews.Title: Run far run fast!!
Reviews.Author: B. Christensen "bcstargazer"
Reviews.Content: If the hardware had any quality it would be a great system. 6 cameras died in the first year, 3 dvr replacements by the factory and it still does not work properly. 3 video cables with shorts from the factory. 2nd HD in the dvr. These units are the epitome of Chinese made crap. Internet accessibility is pretty handy but causes the system to lock up and quit recording. You must be on-site to reboot. Bottom line I am sorry I bought the unit and sorry I did not return it initially. I would not even recommended this unit as a toy.

Reviews.Title: Great starter. Not for capture if you need details.
Reviews.Author: Mike Dibble
Reviews.Content: Being a user and installer of many higher brand cameras and dvr's, I only needed something small and cheap for my home. Being used to spending 10-30,000 on DVR's and cameras from Pelco, Speco, and Hikvision I thought I would give this a whirl for what I needed. People reading this review.. Please understand you get what you pay for. For 400.00 don't be surprised with the results. DVR setup is simple. The onscreen menu either through the remote or mouse is less than friendly. Use the software and setup the DVR remotely once connected to the lan. Cameras are only 400TVL.  At least 480 or 520 will be required if you need the see fine details such as facial features. Led's are less than adequate. I get 10-20 ft of visable distance during the night. Lots of snow as well.  During the day my green grass is PINK. These cameras do NOT have much for adjustment to them to correct the colors. Mainly only brightness. Now I expected this and for a quick fix and only spending 400.00 for a whole system. Im happy enough. This puts me into the position now where I can at least start capturing video and having something which is better than nothing. And I can start upgrading my cameras one at a time. Once I get all the cameras upgraded I can then look at a better DVR. If you need this system for home or business and expect this to be the ONLY thing you need you will be disappointed. If you need something as a starter with hopes to expand or future plans....Then by all means this is a great starting point.  I have added THEIR rendition of some video and added it to this review so you can see what to expect.  You will have to download Q-See software to be able to load and play it back. Although this is a hassle you won't get the ability to export or convert video files until you get into a more expensive system. This is pretty much defacto standard through the whole security realm. Every vendor trys to decode their own flavor on the video instead of using something thats industry standard. H.264 is the compression used to encode the video.  ---correction.-- Video would not upload. Unsupported format.

Reviews.Title: Update the Firmware!
Reviews.Author: Markus
Reviews.Content: I have installed a few of these systems "on the cheap" for some local small businesses.  One of the QS408 DVR's had an older firmware than the others, and I could not update it in November when the newest firmware was released.  The bug in the firmware caused the HDD to become corrupt after it filled, which destroyed all the recordings on the DVR.  Sure enough, we found this out the hard way.If you have one of these. CHECK YOUR RECORDINGS!  Every 2 weeks, make sure you have files.As of now, I check all the systems every pay day.500gb provides about two weeks of recordings. A 1tb drive would do a month, and a 2tb drive would store 2 months.  This is CIF and low bitrate, with motion detection.  When you first install the DVR, FORMAT THE HARD DRIVE!!  Even the factory installed drives should be re-formatted, just to be safe and ensure it is working properly.The CMOS cameras are crap. Go for the CCD cameras, or get your own CCD cameras from somewhere else. The CMOS cameras remind me of webcams in 1999.As for the "FULL D1" option, it is only available on Channel 1 and Channel 2.For the cell phone monitoring, the mEye program works excellent.  Setup your DVR with a static IP on your subnet. Setup a POS computer, the DVR, or the Router for a dyndns.org domain name, and it'll stay updated.  I've heard the paid version of mEye isn't any better, but does offer to view 4 cameras at once.  If you want to pay the extra for a "Static IP" internet address, then you don't have to worry about a dynamic domain name.The newest firmware released in Nov 2011 supports Internet Explorer 9.  If you use the web interface, You have to enable "Safe Sites" and uncheck the "Require https://" checkbox.I'll be upgrading some of these DVR's to use 2TB drives soon, as the people want more than 2 weeks of video on their DVR's.  I'm very impressed for how well they work and at what price.Sure, some people say "made in china crap" but really.. in 2011, how much stuff IS NOT made in China??????  That's the global economy we've created.. now deal with it ;)

Reviews.Title: Ok if you dont want remote acess
Reviews.Author: moe762x39
Reviews.Content: Unit is not very good. I have a nightowl, and ordered this one for my brother. The price looked good for all the features. Once it was hooked up the audio was terrible. Unit kept restarting. The remote access was horrible. It kept freezing up. Sending it back and getting a nightowl.

Reviews.Title: Good buy, but missing an important feature.
Reviews.Author: Campboss
Reviews.Content: The Q-See QS408-5 8 Channel H.264 Smart Recording DVR with Pre-Installed 500GB is a good buy.  The only disappointment so far is that when the display is in the 8 panel mode (showing all 8 camera views), it doesn't go to full screen when a camera detects motion.  I haven't set up the Internet access yet, but it looks like a similar setup for the SVAT dvr that i just sent back for repairs.I've submitted an inquiry to Q-See about the full screen mode and I'm hoping I will be able to come back here and correct my criticism.

Reviews.Title: Value BUT TECH SUPPORT IS HORRIBLE
Reviews.Author: CK
Reviews.Content: UPDATEWe received this system and one of the camera's were DOA! We tested all facets to determine. We then contacts Q-See and they told us we needed to contact the seller. We contacted the seller and they said the ONLY thing we could do with them was RETURN THE WHOLE SYSTEM. Who pays to remove all the cameras and then replace?????? We submitted a claim to Q-See online, we attempted to get an RMA from Q-See via their website which did not work. We emailed Q-See 2 times and even posted our problem on the Q-See Facebook page. NOTHING.....SO DO NOT BUY ANY Q-SEE PRODUCTS. Their support SUCKS. In the end the product is what you pay for. CHeap off shore product only interested in selling boxes but not supporting the product after the sale. HORRIBLE. IF we could rate them ZERO Stars we would.+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++Sure this is a value but in the end you get what you pay for. I have had issues with the system and the configuration to view camera online and via smartphone. The technical support is THE WORST. The first level of support doesn't even have hardware to help support you. Then you have to go through hoops to TRY and get to level 2 support. The manuals are horrible, the online information incomplete and in some examples wrong. I don't care what the value is but as a professional installation technician if I can't get somebody on the phone to assist then how int he world will they support an end user! This is another example of a overseas product that is pushed into the market place and all anybody can see if the cost. For my experience now with 3 installs the value IS NOT worth the savings. If there isn't proper support who cars what the cost is. Other options might be a little more but they offer tech support. If any user has experienced their online tech support submission and how they handle this you know what I mean. Simply horrible and after this current experience I can't recommend this product and will never touch one for a client again. I've installed hundreds of systems from many manufactures but this ranks as the worst support by a long shot. Sorry but the truth.

Reviews.Title: piece of crap! cannot replay video. repair process is a joke!
Reviews.Author: bill in texas
Reviews.Content: Totally frustrating experience. It's been over a month since purchase and no end in sight. The dvr would not allow recorded video to be replayed, rendering it useless. The repair process is totally obtuse - speaking to a personal is practically impossible. They ignore most emails. Seeking refund thru credit card company. Do not do business with q-see!

Reviews.Title: Works great!
Reviews.Author: SumGuy
Reviews.Content: Very nice product!  It was a little bit confusing getting it to work so you could access the cameras over the internet.  But with a 5 minute call to Tech support, they had it running so I could access everything on my computer as well as through my Android-based mobile device.  I have a security system that calls my cell phone when it is triggered, so while I'm away, I can check my cameras to see if it is a false alarm or not.  Pretty awesome!

Reviews.Title: Very disappointed
Reviews.Author: Susan Perry
Reviews.Content: I ordered this camera and had it professionally installed. What the ad does not tell you is that a Q-See installer can be requested.I used someone else. The camera just never worked properly and the installer advised me the hard drive was defective. I contacted thecompany and am waiting for a return authorization. It has been several days. I have emailed and called them but still no authorization.I should have bought this at CompUSA and then I could have returned it. Instead I have spent $445 to have it installed and I still haveno camera. I spent a total of more than $800 - for naught.I am extremely disappointed in this product and the company.

Reviews.Title: Q-See QS408
Reviews.Author: rubenzdotnet
Reviews.Content: To date, still having difficult port forwarding to the net. I have a ATT ethernet modem and Belkin wireless router. Port forwarding software shows possible two routers used. Can't get beyond this obstacle. Other then that, for the price and features, both thumbs up.

Reviews.Title: POOR PRODUCT  NOT AS DESCRIBED
Reviews.Author: Gabriela Villalta
Reviews.Content: The resolution on all the cameras is very poor and also the fisrt day I installed it on at outdoor place and it was fluded with the fist rain.  I wasted my money.  Very dissapointed.

Reviews.Title: Horrible customer service
Reviews.Author: Dan "Dan"
Reviews.Content: First off, Costco often has specials that are very competitive with Amazon vendors.Second, customer service at Q-see is somewhere between unavailable and deplorable.I tried emails, telephone messages, and chat. No luck.  I had to use the wrong telephone promptsand go to customer service because tech support never responded.If you want a decent system at a low price, here it is.  If it is for a high volume user orcommercial application, look elsewhere.

Reviews.Title: Q-see security system
Reviews.Author: Peter Mosten
Reviews.Content: Q-see is one of the worst company I've ever dealt with.I purchased their product and couldn't get it to work.I emailed the company many times before I received anyacknowledgement. When I finally was able to get replacement partsfor the unit, I only had one week left under the warranty.Needless to say, the replacement parts didn't fix the problem.I tried to recontact with the company via email...and they blew meoff until the warranty ran out.After which, they told me they wouldn't even look at the unit..a unit that never worked,unless I paid them $90.00 in advance.  Do not give these thieves your hard earned dollar.Stay far away from Q-see

Reviews.Title: okay but...
Reviews.Author: lg212
Reviews.Content: The system was easy to install because I paid an expert to do it.However and this is the big BUT the programing of the machine is not easy nor is working the system. I believe their software's interface design is not intuitive which is not helped because the remote is a piece of junk, the instructions are difficult and the company's tech support is terrible. So while I am happy the tech support staff is in the USA the company's policy is that they would rather email you their difficult instructions instead of walk you through the difficulties you are facing.Or as others have stated "just leave a message and someone will get back to you." Ha! Ha! hopefully you are home when they call sitting in front of the blasted dvr machine. Now's the time for the expletive...

Reviews.Title: Cameras suck
Reviews.Author: BigJOEB
Reviews.Content: I mounted the cameras on a two story house @17ft and you can't make out faces in the yard 22ft away from the camera in the day. As for the night vision if that is what you call it, I can tell it a person maybe even who it is if I KNOW THEM. I think I may have to light my whole yard (All 500sq ft) hopefully if I catch someone, the cops can digitally enhance it.  I HOPE...As for setting the cameras up it is simple pull one wire put in two connections on the camera and on the DVR...... Oh Yeah my grass is orange unless in full sunlight and then it only has splotches of green.The DVR not so easy to use easy to set up the menu is limited and I still can't figure out how to stop it from record all the time. I clicked stop on the remote but the user guide says it may not be programmed to my DVR. SO I pushed stop on the front of the DVR wait no, that did not work either. So I went into the menu and tried to set it for motion record only and then clicked stop still not stopped. I really wish I would have gone with less cameras and better quality.BummedHey Amazon get your shipping times right, and if you going to offer free shipping then make it free!

Reviews.Title: YOU NEED TO  KNOW SOME NETWORKING KNOWLEDGE
Reviews.Author: rav4
Reviews.Content: nice DVR, easy to hookup, but takes some doing to get online and 3g, just follow directions. The most important part is to establish a STATIC IP address for the unit, then it makes it much easier to manage the device. DOES NOT WORK WITH CHROME, need to use Microsoft Internet Explorer. I hope this helps. I like the device, and i recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Good for close, inside surveillance.
Reviews.Author: Laurie J Jaggers
Reviews.Content: Camera quality is not great but okay if you are using it for close up monitoring. already have a problem with the mouse not working properly. had to setup the internet access to control the DVR. that is a bit complex, and you must have computer knowledge. setup motion detect alarm to email pictures...low resolution and quite small. For a few hunderd buck this would be great for inside surveillance. you'll need better cameras for any distance outside.

Reviews.Title: Don't buy.  Go with a name brand
Reviews.Author: ken
Reviews.Content: Spent 3 full days trying to set up port forwarding for remote access to system.  Still have not been successful.  No phone support for system.  Only e-mail.  Don't bother buying this product.  Go with a name brand.

Reviews.Title: POOR QUALITY
Reviews.Author: T. Lovell "tim35120"
Reviews.Content: Lasted 1 Year and 2 channels went out on receiver.  2 cameras went out within 1 week of each other.  Night vision is horrible.  But hey...you get what you pay for!

Reviews.Title: Excellant choice in security camera DVR's
Reviews.Author: Doc Jim
Reviews.Content: After having gone through 4 DVR's made by other manufacturers, I took the plunge and purchased this model after my Swann DVR failed. This is one of the better recorders I've seen and without spending your last dime on a DVR, this is a very good choice. Once you get used to moving around in the menu system, it's also fairly easy to use. Like with any menu in a DVR system, this one does take some time to get used to. I have the recordings set to 30fps for all channels and have channels 1 and 2 set for "HD".One thing I was leery of was whether or not the Internet Explorer app was going to work. I'm happy to say it works great. (You have to allow IE to download and install it just once) BUT....  The android app that this DVR comes with is almost total garbage although the updated version on the app store works "ok" but not anything to write home about. That app is also available in the app store. Don't bother with it but read on....If you are planning on accessing this DVR system from your android phone or tablet, get the app "IP Cam Viewer" by Robert Chou from the app store. The app works >>>perfect<<< with this DVR and there's a free version and a pay version. Chou's app accesses my QSEE DVR from either my Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 or from my Samsung Galaxy S3 phone.

Reviews.Title: Reliable, great visibility on cameras, but you need to be a computer expert to set it up
Reviews.Author: M. Tolliver
Reviews.Content: We bought our QSee system 2 years ago.  The cameras and the hard drive work great.  However, you need to be a computer expert to be able to set this system up and there are many "quirks" about it.  After we installed 8 cameras, we hired a computer expert to set it up so we can view the cameras and history online and on our smart phone.  However, once we upgraded to the lates version in internet explorer, we can no longer see our cameras on the computer.  Therefore, we left one old computer with the older version of internet explorer in order to be able to check the history on the cameras.It is not a user-friendly system at all.  There is a process of saving any camera footage.  However, with red tape, we can actually go back up to 8 days and find any date / time in the past to save the video if needed.

Reviews.Title: Good Product for the Money - But Use the Q SEE Techs for Help
Reviews.Author: paul getty
Reviews.Content: I had previously purchased a less expensive 4 channel multiplexer and wanted to upgrade to more cameras and an internet connection. Record capability was a plus that I am still not using. In short, after some start-up issues, got the product to work and am very impressed with quality of the images as well as internet accessibility on my PCs and iPAD. I have seen some of the negative reviews and suggest the following:- Work with Q SEE tech folks if you need help opening ports. Most home internet set-ups have one or more firewalls (modem, router) that default to block internet access to view your cameras on line. Opening these ports can be a royal pain - even if you are tech savvy.- Do not waste time with your internet provider - use the Q SEE techs. After discovering that my ports were closed, I first went to my ATT Uverse provider and they sent me to their new Connect Tech people who are based in India. I was on the phone for 2 hours (after paying $49) and they were unable to open the required ports on the ATT Uverse modem. I then called Q SEE and reached "Jean-Paul," a great tech that had me up and running fast with several clear instructions. He even walked me through settings on my old Netgear FSV318 router as well as on the ATT 2Wire modem with more insight than the Connect Tech folks!- Have patience and be prepared to invest some time to get this working. Generally not a plug and play install due to issues with routers and modems - not the Q SEE device. If you have port blocking issues, you will have them with any device - and resolving the issues can be tricky due to your set-up.

Reviews.Title: Half way home
Reviews.Author: Lonley DVR
Reviews.Content: The unit came late with software problems and a missing remote control.  The supplier is slow to respond ever thought they say that HAD?  Does not read emails clearly and avoids the primary question.  More hundreds of bucks not doing the job.  I can not log into my new DVR as I type this!  I had a unit like this and the program went bad so I had to spend hundreds for a new unit with a program that does not work correctly like the first DRV never did and finally stopped working!  Cheaper to get a dog and have the neighbor feed it.  Dogs last longer than DVRs and never brake!This is my 5 DVR!  Guess I must spend the grand!How many people sell computers that will not give you a copy of the program!  We this is one!  Incredible!  Too bad they have NO QA as well!

Reviews.Title: Good Quality
Reviews.Author: Momen
Reviews.Content: This is very good system to install. But Its power out let is not to good. Power is gone in a little shake and system shut off.Momen

Reviews.Title: So Far So Good
Reviews.Author: Dracis
Reviews.Content: Installed the system a few months ago.  So far so good..  all 8 cameras are functioning with no issue.  Night vision is excellent on the front and back door..  A little less clear looking into the front and back yards at night, but that is to be expected (still have a good 30 feet of viewing area).I set up the system so it can be viewed remotely from any computer or from my wife's smartphone.The only con is that being from Florida, we have many bugs flying at night.  Motion sensing (even at its least sensitive setting) is constantly going off - so I shutoff the alarm for that feature.

Reviews.Title: Excellent value for the money
Reviews.Author: Ceferino Jimenez
Reviews.Content: Excellent unit, good tech support, it is a real time DVR, plays and record real time (like viewing a movie on your TV)

Reviews.Title: Good
Reviews.Author: Marylin S.
Reviews.Content: excellent product, Anything agains this DVC and easy instalation if you know a little bit about. Not problem at all

Reviews.Title: Terrible. Buy another brand
Reviews.Author: Lucis Ferre "Lucis Ferre"
Reviews.Content: Lasted 1 year. Two channels went out on receiver and I can no longer download video footage. The night vision is terrible. What a piece of trash.

Reviews.Title: Works as it should
Reviews.Author: Justin Quigley "Justin Quigley"
Reviews.Content: I have been getting Q-see DVRs for about 4 years now. They have definitely advanced their software in that period. I get about 2 1/2 weeks of recording time out of the 500GB hdd. Which isn't that bad considering i have alot of traffic come through my office. The lag from internet viewing is a little annoying. I wish they had a master stream function like they did in their old DVR's. I will keep purchasing these though.

Reviews.Title: Review
Reviews.Author: Matt
Reviews.Content: The product was exceptional and exactly as described. This particular device was not wireless and after inspection, realized it would not work well for what we needed due to wiring, so we had to return the product.

Reviews.Title: Complete garbage
Reviews.Author: Michael Perez
Reviews.Content: Quality: Terrible.A 20 dollar USB camera for video chatting has better resolution than the cameras that come with this system. It's an insult as a security camera at best even after you take the time to adjust the video settings. I can't even tell someone's face even 15 feet away....Software: Terrible.Poor design, just something slapped together with a ton of buttons with no real organization. Viewing videos remotely does not work properly more than half the time.Android App: Never worked.This never worked with Gingerbread or Jellybean. Just as nasty as the software for the machine however at least that worked.Firmware: Horrible.Login does not work half the time and the recommended fix is to downgrade to IE8...which is not a fix at all its just them telling you to go screw yourself because we don't plan on updating this thing ever again.Overall: Terrible.Spent a good chunk of change on this system and I never plan on using another Q-See product again. I would not recommend this product to anyone who actually plans on having something that actually works as a security system.

Reviews.Title: buy from costco
Reviews.Author: xenon hid
Reviews.Content: i bought other unit from Costco camera quality is best and same price but this unit is very complicated and cheap quality

Reviews.Title: Great video recorder for the money but wish it had an easier way to export video.
Reviews.Author: Jonathan C. Nook
Reviews.Content: Great video recorder for the money but wish it had an easier way to export video.I think if Apple made this product, the UI would be a lot more user friendly, and logical, but for the money it's very hard to beat. This replaces a system, we had, that was almost 10 times the price, and works just as well.

Reviews.Title: OK DVR but low quality cameras
Reviews.Author: Sully
Reviews.Content: They system as a whole is OK, if I hadn't purchased better cameras I wouldn't have known just how bad the ones in this kit are.  For an entry level system I think it works great, the cameras are just lacking night time visibilty.

Reviews.Title: Good but could be better
Reviews.Author: Clint Reuter
Reviews.Content: Seems like a great product, just could use an easier navigation system once connected to a monitor. Not sure how to go back and see old video or sure if my settings are right and who has time for all that!The video seems good and my neighbor got vandalized and it didn't capture the street at night as well as I had hoped.

Reviews.Title: not what was advertised
Reviews.Author: glenn black
Reviews.Content: it didnt have a loop feed where i could view it from televisions in my housealso it came w the incoorect power cord that took 3 weeks of interegation and passed around the office at q see

Reviews.Title: no good
Reviews.Author: robert
Reviews.Content: the box came open and im missing the instruction dvd so i cant even set it up with out it

Reviews.Title: Works well for the Price.
Reviews.Author: Larry
Reviews.Content: The only thing we do not like about this purchase?  That the cameras cannot be adjusted for zoom.  The cameras are good for about 10 - 15ft.  That's it.  So if you want to place them high up, then good luck.

Reviews.Title: STAY AWAY!!! - But NOT ANYMORE!
Reviews.Author: John in Amelia Island
Reviews.Content: INITIAL REVIEW:The Q-See is a POS! It is extremely difficult to set up. Support is horrible. If I could give it zero stars, I would. Spend a bit more and get something that works.UPDATE (AFTER SEVERAL MONTHS OF TROUBLE FREE OPERATION): Once I figured out how to manage the IP address issue, the camera has been trouble free through power failures and unplugging it from the router. The trick of this is to first set it up to "Obtain IP Address Automatically," then, once the IP address is obtained, un-check the automatic option so that the IP address remains static. Then, it works. Also Q-See has greatly updated its interface software for PC and iPhone/Android, so monitoring works well.I recommend this highly for the price, but be prepared for a headache until you get it set up. During this phase, keep thinking of the money you saved over systems that may actually be no easier to set up.Finally, Q-See help desk is pretty good via email and phone.

Reviews.Title: Junk DVR
Reviews.Author: Agent Terry
Reviews.Content: This is the worst piece of junk I have ever purchased.  I have spent hundred's of dollar hours trying to get this set up and get help from the stupid on line store I purchased it from. They refuse to help  and told me to seek professional help for setup. Hello what a fricken joke. There is no manual guide that matches the software installed on my dvr. the Menu is totally different and must be a old . old version. Dont buy this h264 8 channel network Dvr 8.2.8. PO2R . Ports dont work. IP dont work. dyndns dont work. nothing works. connections fail,there is no Live mode to set up in Main menu, but it has a cute blue light that does work. What a nightmare.

Reviews.Title: Q-See QS-408-811-5
Reviews.Author: Caribbean Amphibian
Reviews.Content: The nightvision feature of one of the eight cameras was not working. Cameras mountedoutside in areas with bright sunlight doesn't provide clear footage, the video looks bleached.

Reviews.Title: great
Reviews.Author: Chris
Reviews.Content: If u rate this at 4 star and below then you need help. It dose everything it says. SSimple works . Mobile view is great . Dvr is good 5start here. Everyone else that give it lower than 4 stars you can suck it. Good product easy customers service. But this model install by its self very easy.

Reviews.Title: great product
Reviews.Author: RobertJ
Reviews.Content: This product works as advertised, I have trouble with it using a wireless camera if there is much snow in the picture for motion detection.

Reviews.Title: great stuff
Reviews.Author: Joey Cellular Unlocking "Joey"
Reviews.Content: works great, shows crystal clear, no problems at all!so i have to buy a third set, how do i get a discount?

Reviews.Title: Security Equipment
Reviews.Author: shop talk
Reviews.Content: This was purchased to monitor a small business and we couldn't be happier.  The quality is great and the product is very easy to use.  We ended up purchasing two more for our other locations.

Reviews.Title: Satisfied purchase
Reviews.Author: lleb1268
Reviews.Content: I purchased this product on the reviews of others who have bought it. Upon receiving my cameras and additional wiring I hooked the camera up and tested before I installed them.  What I found was impressive. The cameras give you a good clean view not only during the day but also at night. These camera actually replace a set of wireless cameras that I had nothing but problems with since I installed them. I plan on installing another 500 gig hard drive for additional drive space. Over all I am satisfied with the cameras and the output that they produce. The only thing that I would suggest is that the instructions were a little bit clearer specially on adjusting the cameras. Very satisfied and for the price of this system your getting a great deal.

Reviews.Title: So far so good
Reviews.Author: Tensy
Reviews.Content: Simple easy to setup.  Even a caveman can do it.  Got a quote from a security company for $5,000 to do this.  Lot's of cool options.

Reviews.Title: Pretty Satisfied..
Reviews.Author: ChuckEPT
Reviews.Content: The system was extremely easy to install. The clarity on the cameras was very good, however I was hoping the movement was a bit more than available. As an example, I was hoping to place the camera on a wall that did not face the street and simply move rotate the camera to capture the front area of my house. I was unable to this, due to the rotation arm having limited flexibility and the camera not having a rotate option.This was the only improvement I might expect for the do-it-yourselfer. Beyond that, the DVR is extremely easy to configure and so far I have had no issues. Night vision is pretty cool, although moths seem to trigger a capture event...not a big deal, but worth noting.Enjoy

Reviews.Title: securitie cameras
Reviews.Author: Carlos
Reviews.Content: love them already help caught people doing property damage at a were church and they have paid for them self.

Reviews.Title: VERY GOOD PRODUCT
Reviews.Author: Jose Salas
Reviews.Content: Soy de Venezuela y es un producto muy completo y lo recomiendo 100% tiene muy buena calidad de imagen y cumple con el trabajo tal cual como lo necesito

Reviews.Title: Very good
Reviews.Author: entucalator
Reviews.Content: Producto en perfectas condiciones muy bueno, a tiempo y justo lo que pedi, ninguna queja. Todo en orden y correcto. Muy satisfecho con la compra

Reviews.Title: Problem in this device
Reviews.Author: jhonny fabian
Reviews.Content: HelloI have a qs408 from one moment to another, does not display video when the button turns on lights only NET and the team does not signal to the display, which can be, thanks, as you can reset the computerin this momment this device not function.

Reviews.Title: Q-SEE PACKAGE
Reviews.Author: Poppin Dollar "electronics freak"
Reviews.Content: i purchased an eight camera pkg. from another vendor (which i decline to name) becuz i enjoy shopping "AMAZON" & do not want 2 tout some1 else on this web site) that was on sale to replace some ancient G.E. units. the units where spectacular but the sale ended & that item became unavailable @ any price. searching AMAZON i found these & even though they had less nite illumination at the same price as the sale item i thought they would suffice. No! No! Nanette. and the HARD DRIVE HAD ISSUES. however  thanx to the amazon EXCELLENT CUSTOMER SERVICE I GOT A FULL refund. so i m a disappointed but still happy camper. i might add that if not 4 the hard drive issues & the side by side caparison i might have attempted to work w these. some other reviewers found them acceptable, but not myself.

Reviews.Title: I have seen better.
Reviews.Author: GNC111
Reviews.Content: this unit didn't come with the cable to hook up 8 cameras. I am not happy with this. I cancelled the order within 10 minutes after ordering it but... Amazon sent it anyway. I have seen better models for less money that include the cables.I will be returning this.

Reviews.Title: Q-See QS408-411-5
Reviews.Author: Angel M. Torres "mtorres"
Reviews.Content: Easy to install, colors not good, night vision Ok. I haven't try to connected to the internet yet, I read it is too complicate. I'll try it when I have the time.

ProductInfo.Features:
Advanced H.264 Video Compression
CIF Real-Time Recording (30FPS per channel x 8 cameras = 240FPS Total) / D1 Recording Option (7.5FPS per channel x 8 cameras = 60FPS Total)
Stream Live Video Directly to a remote PC, iPhone, iPad, Android, or other
Backup important video from the DVR to a PC or Flash Drive
Pre-Installed 500GB Hard Drive;DVR Supports up to 8 Security Cameras
Trigger Email Alerts on Motion Detection Events. Supported Smartphone Running Windows Mobile Pro or Symbian on 3G Networks.
ProductInfo.Name: Q-See QS408-803-5 Precision Recording Security System with 8 Indoor/Outdoor CCD Cameras and Pre-Installed 500GB Hard Drive
